title: Responsive Design with Bootstrap
author: Emil Jacobsson
description: Bootstrap is a helpful toolkit for web development. It's quite popular and makes it easier to create good-looking websites that work well on different devices. Bootstrap was initially created by Twitter developers, and now many other people contribute to it.With Bootstrap, you get many pre-built components like buttons, forms, and menus. These components use HTML, CSS, and JavaScript, which help web developers save time and effort since they don't have to build everything from scratch.One of the best features of Bootstrap is its responsive design. This means that websites made with Bootstrap can automatically adapt to various screen sizes, like desktop computers, laptops, tablets, and smartphones. It uses a grid system to organize the layout into rows and columns.Bootstrap also has many pre-designed themes and styles that you can customize to match the look you want for your website. This is a big time-saver for developers and helps to keep a consistent design across different projects.To use Bootstrap in web development, you just need to include the framework's files (CSS and JavaScript) in your HTML file. Then, you can use the pre-defined classes and components provided by Bootstrap to build your website.In short, Bootstrap is a user-friendly web development framework that makes it simpler for developers to create responsive and visually appealing websites. It offers pre-built components, a flexible grid system, and various themes to help save time and maintain consistency in web projects.

title: HTML - an introduction
author: Albert Gustavsson
description: HTML(HyperText Markup Language), is the basic building block used to create websites. It's a simple language that helps you structure and organize content on a webpage, like text, images, and links.In HTML, you use something called tags to create the structure of a webpage. Tags are like little labels that tell the web browser how to display the content. For example, you might use the < p> tag to create a paragraph or the < h1> tag for a big heading. You usually have an opening tag, like < p>, and a closing tag, like < /p>, that wraps around the content.HTML documents have a standard structure, which starts with a < !DOCTYPE html> declaration to let the browser know it's dealing with an HTML file. Then, you'll have an opening < html> tag and a closing < /html> tag. Inside the HTML tags, you'll find two main sections: the < head> and the < body>. The < head> section contains information about the page, like its title, and links to external files like CSS or JavaScript. The < body> section is where you put all the content you want to show on the webpage, like text, images, and links.One important thing to know about HTML is that it's not a programming language. It doesn't have logic or functions like JavaScript or Python. Instead, it's a markup language that helps you structure and organize content on a webpage. To create a webpage with HTML, you write the HTML code in a text editor and save it with a .html file extension. You can then open the file in a web browser to see how it looks. As you learn more about HTML, you can combine it with other languages like CSS (for styling) and JavaScript (for interactivity) to create more advanced websites.In summary, HTML is a simple language used to structure content on webpages. It uses tags to organize elements like text, images, and links, and it's the foundation of every website. Learning HTML is an essential first step for anyone interested in web development.

title: CSS - an Introduction
author: Franke Svantesson
description: CSS, which stands for Cascading Style Sheets, is a language used in web development to style and design the appearance of websites. While HTML helps structure the content on a webpage, CSS makes it look visually appealing by controlling things like colors, fonts, and layouts.CSS works by using selectors to target specific HTML elements on a webpage. These selectors can be based on the element's tag, class, or ID. Once you've targeted an element, you can apply properties to it. Properties are like instructions that tell the browser how to style the element. For example, you might use the color property to change the text color or the background-color property to change the background color.You can use CSS in different ways when building a website: Inline CSS: You can add CSS directly to an HTML tag using the style attribute. However, this method can be hard to manage for larger projects and isn't recommended for most cases. Internal CSS: You can include CSS inside the < style> tags in the < head> section of your HTML document. This method is useful for small projects but can become difficult to maintain as your project grows. External CSS: The best practice is to create a separate CSS file (with a .css file extension) and link it to your HTML document using the < link> tag in the < head> section. This way, you can keep your styles organized and easily update them across multiple webpages.When using CSS, it's essential to understand the cascading part of its name. It means that if you have multiple styles applied to the same HTML element, the browser will use a set of rules to determine which style takes precedence. This usually depends on the specificity of the selector and the order in which the styles are defined. In conclusion, CSS is a language used to style and design websites, making them visually appealing. It works alongside HTML to create beautiful webpages with custom colors, fonts, and layouts. Learning CSS is a crucial step for anyone interested in web development, as it allows you to create professional-looking websites and improve the user experience.

title: JavaScript - an Introduction
author: Per Karlsson
description: JavaScript is a programming language used in web development to make websites interactive and dynamic. While HTML helps with structuring content and CSS takes care of styling, JavaScript adds functionality and brings websites to life by adding features like animations, form validation, and user interactions. JavaScript works by using scripts, which are pieces of code that you write to tell the browser what actions to perform. You can include JavaScript directly in your HTML document by placing it between < script> tags, usually at the bottom of the < body> section. Alternatively, you can create a separate JavaScript file (with a .js file extension) and link it to your HTML document using the src attribute in the < script> tag. One of the main features of JavaScript is that it's an event-driven language. This means that it can respond to various events happening on a webpage, like a button being clicked or a form being submitted. To do this, you write functions, which are blocks of code that perform specific tasks. You can then connect these functions to events using event listeners. JavaScript is also capable of interacting with HTML and CSS, allowing you to manipulate the content, structure, and style of a webpage in real-time. This is achieved through a feature called the Document Object Model (DOM), which represents the structure of a webpage as a tree of objects. By using JavaScript, you can access and modify these objects to change the webpage's appearance and behavior. In recent years, JavaScript has expanded beyond just web development. With the help of technologies like Node.js, you can now use JavaScript to build server-side applications and even create desktop or mobile apps. In summary, JavaScript is a versatile programming language that plays a crucial role in web development. It allows developers to create interactive and dynamic websites by adding features like animations, form validation, and user interactions. Learning JavaScript is an important step for anyone interested in web development, as it opens up a wide range of possibilities for creating engaging and user-friendly websites and applications.
